Gold is not as expensive as people think it is, also, only nanofilms are needed, tiny amounts!


[quote]Quote:[hr]Hmm, I think that generating a magnetic field like that would interfere way too much with the onboard electronics. Just think of what you'd if you saw someone putting a magnet to your HD.[hr][/quote]

It would depend onthe field strength, and most importantly if it were moving or varying; a steady magnetic field is much less problematic.

[quote]Quote:[hr]On the other hand, Earth's magnetic field exists all the time and it is protective enough, and I don't see hard drives being wiped all the time, lol, so maybe it is possible.[hr][/quote]

The Earth's magnetic field is set at about 4 x 10 -3 Tesla; rather weak. A fridge magnet is hundreds of times stronger. Though since it's made of layered magnets, its field barely extends above the surface. Not only the field strength, but its extent is important, Earth's field is weak, but extends a long way, and has the buffering of the Van Allen belts and solar wind.

[quote]Quote:[hr]the Aurora Australis/Borealis that you can see over the Earth's magnetic poles is caused by the remnants of solar flares coming into contact with the Earth's magnetic field,[hr][/quote]

Actually they are high energy particles, both from space and the sun, mostly protons, that are caught in the Van Allen belts where they spin around and around, desperatly trying to get out. Near the poles the magnetic field dips and the particles can hit the atmosphere, giving up their energy as light.

For a spaceship to do the same, it would need somewhere for the field to dip, maybe onto the craft's surface.

title: Re: Space Craft windows
content: Turning something electric on and off only makes a *really* small magnetic field though, and it only lasts for a fraction of a second - the 'thunk' you hear when you turn a CRT on (be it a TV or a computer monitor) is the degauss circuit, which is an electrical coil wrapped around the outside of the tube, specifically designed to produce a strong magnetic field.  The field is strong enough that in a cheap TV you can hear it vibrate for the first few seconds after the TV is switched on (after two or three seconds the degauss circuit is switched off again.)  In digital computer monitors you can also trigger the degauss circuit from the on-screen menu, which gives you the same 'thunk' as when you first switch the monitor on (although it's usually more like a click or a buzz, given the smaller size of most monitors compared to a large TV.)
